newsitem.title: UK: LME slow, copper lifted by covering by close.
newsitem.headline: LME slow, copper lifted by covering by close.

text.p: Base metals by the close of Friday's London Metal Exchange (LME) floor trading remained uninspiring, though book squaring ahead of the long U.K. holiday weekend helped to move copper higher.

Traders said bouts of short covering lifted copper from a low of $1,932 to $1,949, a $14 gain from Thursday, though the market never seriously attempted to break from its recent well-worn range of between $1,900 and $1,970.
"Overall copper market activity has been dire," one said.
He believed the lack of market moving news and strong physical interest may continue after the U.K Monday holiday.
There will be no LME stocks report on Tuesday.
The next return will be on Friday August 30.
Other metals remained sluggish depite the uptick in the copper market.
Nickel maintained levels above $7,400 amid short covering following its recent robust chart performance. But overhead selling and profit-taking restricted further gains.
Trade selling in thin trading knocked zinc by $6 to $1,024, while lead dipped by $11 to $807.
Aluminium slipped to test support levels, though found some solace from light consumer demand. It was last at $1,478, against $1,487.
Tin moved $5 higher to $6,170, while alloy was last quoted at $1,280/90, against $1,285.
